alopecia.png.name: Alopecia
alopecia.png.description: Hair loss in dogs, which can be caused by various factors including parasites, allergies, hormonal imbalances, or stress.
alopecia.png.precautions: Identify and treat the underlying cause. Consult a vet for diagnosis. Medicated shampoos or topical treatments may help. Ensure a balanced diet.

Canine Atopic Dermatitis.png.name: Canine Atopic Dermatitis
Canine Atopic Dermatitis.png.description: An allergic skin disease causing chronic itching, often triggered by environmental allergens like pollen, mold spores, or dust mites.
Canine Atopic Dermatitis.png.precautions: Minimize allergen exposure. Use vet-prescribed antihistamines or immunotherapy. Regular bathing with hypoallergenic shampoos can soothe skin. Omega-3 fatty acid supplements may help.

Contact Allergies.png.name: Contact Allergies
Contact Allergies.png.description: Skin reaction caused by direct contact with an allergen, such as certain plants, chemicals in shampoos or bedding, or materials like plastic or rubber.
Contact Allergies.png.precautions: Identify and avoid the specific allergen. Wash the affected area gently. Topical corticosteroids or antihistamines may be prescribed by a vet.

dermatitis.jpeg.name: Dermatitis (General)
dermatitis.jpeg.description: General inflammation of the skin, which can manifest as redness, itching, swelling, or lesions. Can have many causes.
dermatitis.jpeg.precautions: Determine the specific type and cause with a vet. Treatment varies widely based on the cause (e.g., antibiotics for bacterial infection, antifungals for yeast).

ear infections.png.name: Ear Infections (Otitis Externa)
ear infections.png.description: Inflammation or infection of the external ear canal, often caused by bacteria, yeast, allergies, or ear mites. Symptoms include head shaking, scratching, odor, and discharge.
ear infections.png.precautions: Keep ears clean and dry, especially after swimming or bathing. Treat underlying allergies. Use vet-prescribed ear cleaners and medications.

Folliculitis.jpg.name: Folliculitis
Folliculitis.jpg.description: Inflammation of the hair follicles, often due to bacterial infection. Appears as small pimples, bumps, or scabs on the skin.
Folliculitis.jpg.precautions: Keep skin clean. Use antibacterial shampoos or wipes as directed by a vet. Oral antibiotics may be necessary for deeper infections.

hot spots.jpeg.name: Hot Spots (Acute Moist Dermatitis)
hot spots.jpeg.description: Localized areas of skin inflammation and bacterial infection that appear suddenly and can worsen rapidly. Often triggered by allergies, insect bites, or excessive licking.
hot spots.jpeg.precautions: Clip hair around the area, clean gently with antiseptic solution, and apply vet-prescribed topical medication. Prevent licking (e-collar). Address underlying cause.

Immune-Mediated Diseases.jpeg.name: Immune-Mediated Skin Disease
Immune-Mediated Diseases.jpeg.description: Conditions where the dog's immune system mistakenly attacks parts of the skin, leading to various lesions, ulcers, or crusting (e.g., Pemphigus).
Immune-Mediated Diseases.jpeg.precautions: Requires veterinary diagnosis (often biopsy). Treatment usually involves immunosuppressive drugs prescribed by a vet. Avoid triggers if known.

lick_granuloma.jpg.name: Lick Granuloma (Acral Lick Dermatitis)
lick_granuloma.jpg.description: A skin lesion, typically on the lower leg, caused by chronic, compulsive licking. Often linked to boredom, stress, anxiety, or underlying pain/allergy.
lick_granuloma.jpg.precautions: Address the underlying cause (physical or psychological). Prevent licking (e-collar, bandages). Behavior modification, medication, or laser therapy may be needed. Consult a vet and possibly a behaviorist.

mange.png.name: Mange (Demodectic or Sarcoptic)
mange.png.description: Skin disease caused by mites. Demodectic mange is common in puppies; Sarcoptic mange (scabies) is contagious (including to humans) and very itchy.
mange.png.precautions: Veterinary diagnosis is crucial to identify the type of mite. Treatment involves specific antiparasitic medications (dips, spot-ons, oral). Isolate dogs with Sarcoptic mange.

Pyoderma.jpg.name: Pyoderma
Pyoderma.jpg.description: A bacterial skin infection, often secondary to another condition like allergies or parasites. Can be superficial or deep, causing pus-filled bumps, crusts, and hair loss.
Pyoderma.jpg.precautions: Treat with vet-prescribed antibiotics (topical or oral). Use antibacterial shampoos. Address the underlying cause to prevent recurrence.

ringworm.jpeg.name: Ringworm (Dermatophytosis)
ringworm.jpeg.description: A fungal infection of the skin, hair, and nails (not caused by a worm). Causes circular patches of hair loss, scaling, and sometimes redness. Contagious to other animals and humans.
ringworm.jpeg.precautions: Isolate infected animals. Treat with vet-prescribed antifungal medications (topical and/or oral). Disinfect environment thoroughly (bedding, grooming tools).

Seborrhea.png.name: Seborrhea
Seborrhea.png.description: A condition causing flaky skin (dandruff) and sometimes greasiness. Can be primary (genetic) or secondary to other issues like allergies or hormonal problems.
Seborrhea.png.precautions: Use medicated shampoos designed for seborrhea. Treat underlying causes if secondary. Omega-3 supplements may help. Consult a vet for diagnosis.

Skin Tumors.png.name: Skin Tumors
Skin Tumors.png.description: Abnormal growths on the skin, which can be benign (like warts or cysts) or malignant (cancerous, like mast cell tumors or melanoma).
Skin Tumors.png.precautions: Any new lump or bump should be examined by a vet. Diagnosis often requires biopsy or fine-needle aspirate. Treatment depends on the type of tumor (surgery, chemotherapy, etc.).

Ticks.png.name: Ticks / Tick Bites
Ticks.png.description: Parasites that attach to the skin and feed on blood. Can transmit diseases like Lyme disease, Ehrlichiosis, and Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever.
Ticks.png.precautions: Use regular tick prevention (spot-ons, collars, oral medication). Check dog thoroughly after walks, especially in wooded or grassy areas. Remove ticks promptly and carefully using tweezers. Monitor bite site for irritation or infection.

Yeast Infections.png.name: Yeast Infection (Malassezia Dermatitis)
Yeast Infections.png.description: Overgrowth of yeast normally found on the skin, often triggered by allergies or moisture. Causes itching, redness, greasy skin, hair loss, and a distinct odor.
Yeast Infections.png.precautions: Treat with vet-prescribed antifungal shampoos, wipes, or medications (topical/oral). Keep skin dry. Manage underlying allergies.
